title: Cervical Cancer Treatments
author: Katie Cameron

content: If you were diagnosed with cervical cancer, know that it’s usually very treatable — especially if your doctor caught it early. There are several options to treat it, relieve your symptoms, and help you live longer.

First, your doctor will have to find out the cancer’s stage, meaning its size and whether it has spread to other parts of the body. They will choose a treatment that's most likely to shrink the cancer based on the stage and what type of cervical cancer it is.
They will also consider your age and whether you want to maintain your ability to have children.
Cervical cancer treatments include:
Take time to review all your options. Make sure you understand how each treatment works. If you're not sure about something, ask questions. You can also get a second opinion from another doctor.

content_blocks.text: If you were diagnosed with cervical cancer, know that it’s usually very treatable — especially if your doctor caught it early. There are several options to treat it, relieve your symptoms, and help you live longer.

First, your doctor will have to find out the cancer’s stage, meaning its size and whether it has spread to other parts of the body. They will choose a treatment that's most likely to shrink the cancer based on the stage and what type of cervical cancer it is.
They will also consider your age and whether you want to maintain your ability to have children.
Cervical cancer treatments include:
Take time to review all your options. Make sure you understand how each treatment works. If you're not sure about something, ask questions. You can also get a second opinion from another doctor.

sections.heading: Cervical Cancer Surgery
content: Surgery is the main cervical cancer treatment. Sometimes you'll get chemotherapy or radiation to shrink the tumor before surgery or to kill cancer cells that remain. The type of surgery you have depends on how large the cancer has grown and whether it has spread.

content_blocks.text: Surgery is the main cervical cancer treatment. Sometimes you'll get chemotherapy or radiation to shrink the tumor before surgery or to kill cancer cells that remain. The type of surgery you have depends on how large the cancer has grown and whether it has spread.

content: Some types of cervical cancer surgery can affect your ability to have children. Talk to your doctor about the risks before you decide on a procedure.

Conization. This surgery can treat very small cervical cancers that haven't spread. Your surgeon removes a cone-shaped area of abnormal cells from your cervix. Conization is performed with a knife, laser, or a thin, heated wire loop. After conization, you should still be able to have children.
Total hysterectomy . This surgery removes your uterus and cervix. It is the main treatment for small cancers that haven't spread outside your cervix.
This procedure can be done through your:
During the procedure, your surgeon might also remove your fallopian tubes and ovaries, as well as the lymph nodes in your pelvis to see if the cancer has spread.
You’ll have to stay in the hospital for one to five days after a hysterectomy. Recovery time is faster for laparoscopic surgery than abdominal surgery.
bullets: Belly, through very small holes (laparoscopic hysterectomy)

content_blocks.text: Some types of cervical cancer surgery can affect your ability to have children. Talk to your doctor about the risks before you decide on a procedure.

Conization. This surgery can treat very small cervical cancers that haven't spread. Your surgeon removes a cone-shaped area of abnormal cells from your cervix. Conization is performed with a knife, laser, or a thin, heated wire loop. After conization, you should still be able to have children.
Total hysterectomy . This surgery removes your uterus and cervix. It is the main treatment for small cancers that haven't spread outside your cervix.
This procedure can be done through your:
associated_bullets: Belly, through very small holes (laparoscopic hysterectomy)

content_blocks.text: During the procedure, your surgeon might also remove your fallopian tubes and ovaries, as well as the lymph nodes in your pelvis to see if the cancer has spread.
You’ll have to stay in the hospital for one to five days after a hysterectomy. Recovery time is faster for laparoscopic surgery than abdominal surgery.

content: You won’t be able to have children after a hysterectomy. If you still want kids and opt to have this procedure, talk to your doctor about options such as freezing your eggs or embryos.

Radical hysterectomy. During a radical hysterectomy, your doctor removes your uterus and cervix, along with ligaments that hold your uterus in place, and the top part of the vagina next to the cervix. Pelvic lymph nodes may also be removed.
The surgery is usually done with one large cut in the abdomen or is laparoscopic-assisted through the vagina.

Your hospital stay after a radical hysterectomy is usually between five and seven days. You could have trouble going to the bathroom after surgery, and you might need a temporary tube called a catheter to urinate.

Modified radical hysterectomy . This surgery is usually for early-stage cervical cancer that has not spread outside the cervix. This procedure is similar to a radical hysterectomy, but in this case, less of the vagina and tissue near the uterus is removed. Usually, the lymph nodes aren't removed during a modified radical hysterectomy.

content_blocks.text: You won’t be able to have children after a hysterectomy. If you still want kids and opt to have this procedure, talk to your doctor about options such as freezing your eggs or embryos.

Radical hysterectomy. During a radical hysterectomy, your doctor removes your uterus and cervix, along with ligaments that hold your uterus in place, and the top part of the vagina next to the cervix. Pelvic lymph nodes may also be removed.
The surgery is usually done with one large cut in the abdomen or is laparoscopic-assisted through the vagina.

Your hospital stay after a radical hysterectomy is usually between five and seven days. You could have trouble going to the bathroom after surgery, and you might need a temporary tube called a catheter to urinate.

Modified radical hysterectomy . This surgery is usually for early-stage cervical cancer that has not spread outside the cervix. This procedure is similar to a radical hysterectomy, but in this case, less of the vagina and tissue near the uterus is removed. Usually, the lymph nodes aren't removed during a modified radical hysterectomy.

sections.heading: Trachelectomy.
content: This procedure, also known as a cervicectomy, is an option if you have early-stage cervical cancer and still want to have children. It removes the cervix and top of the vagina but leaves most of the uterus. This can be done through an open cut or laparoscopically in the abdomen or can be done vaginally. If you get pregnant , you'll have to deliver by C-section.

Pelvic exenteration. This surgery is used when cervical cancer comes back and spreads outside the cervix. Your surgeon will remove your cervix, uterus, and nearby lymph nodes. Other organs, like the bladder, vagina, rectum, and part of the colon , might also be removed, depending on where your cancer has spread. If you have your bladder or rectum removed, the surgeon will create new pathways to remove urine and waste from your body.

sections.heading: Radiation Therapy for Cervical Cancer
content: Radiation uses high-energy X-rays to kill cancer cells and stop their growth. You might get radiation before or after surgery or if your cancer has spread beyond your cervix.

content_blocks.text: Radiation uses high-energy X-rays to kill cancer cells and stop their growth. You might get radiation before or after surgery or if your cancer has spread beyond your cervix.

sections.heading: Radiation Therapy for Cervical Cancer
content: Radiation uses high-energy X-rays to kill cancer cells and stop their growth. You might get radiation before or after surgery or if your cancer has spread beyond your cervix.

content_blocks.text: Radiation uses high-energy X-rays to kill cancer cells and stop their growth. You might get radiation before or after surgery or if your cancer has spread beyond your cervix.

content: You can get radiation treatments in two ways.

Brachytherapy. You get radiation through a small device placed inside your body, near your cervix. This is done for early-stage cervical cancer. This type of cervical cancer treatment can be given in the hospital or sometimes at home.

External-beam radiation therapy. EBRT is often combined with brachytherapy to keep advanced cervical cancer from coming back. The radiation is given from a machine outside your body in short bursts once a day, five days a week, for five to six weeks.
Side effects of radiation may include:
These side effects usually go away once you finish treatment.
bullets: Discomfort and urge to urinate often
Swollen legs (if lymph nodes are irradiated)

content_blocks.text: You can get radiation treatments in two ways.

Side effects of radiation may include:
associated_bullets: Discomfort and urge to urinate often
Swollen legs (if lymph nodes are irradiated)

content_blocks.text: These side effects usually go away once you finish treatment.

sections.heading: Chemotherapy for Cervical Cancer
content: During “chemo,” drugs are used to kill or slow the growth of cervical cancer cells. You'll usually get chemo through an IV.
For cervical cancer, doctors often give chemo with radiation, called chemoradiation. Adding chemo makes the radiation work better. You might also get chemotherapy if your cancer has spread.
Combining chemotherapy with radiation may help your treatment work better. (Photo Credit: Digital Vision/Getty Images)

content_blocks.text: During “chemo,” drugs are used to kill or slow the growth of cervical cancer cells. You'll usually get chemo through an IV.
For cervical cancer, doctors often give chemo with radiation, called chemoradiation. Adding chemo makes the radiation work better. You might also get chemotherapy if your cancer has spread.
Combining chemotherapy with radiation may help your treatment work better. (Photo Credit: Digital Vision/Getty Images)

content: The side effects from chemotherapy depend on which drugs you take, but they can include:

Getting both radiation and chemo as cervical cancer treatment can increase the number of side effects you have. Many of these usually go away once you stop treatment. Some can last for a long time, or even permanently. Ask your doctor about ways to relieve your side effects.

content_blocks.text: The side effects from chemotherapy depend on which drugs you take, but they can include:

Getting both radiation and chemo as cervical cancer treatment can increase the number of side effects you have. Many of these usually go away once you stop treatment. Some can last for a long time, or even permanently. Ask your doctor about ways to relieve your side effects.

sections.heading: Targeted Therapy for Cervical Cancer
content: Targeted therapy uses drugs that kill cancer cells but spare healthy cells. For example, bevacizumab (Avastin) is a drug that stops new blood vessels from forming. This can slow down tumor growth in advanced cervical cancer because tumors need new blood vessels for nourishment. Doctors often use targeted therapy with chemotherapy as a cervical cancer treatment. Side effects include high blood pressure, fatigue, loss of appetite, and blood clots or bleeding.

Tisotumab vedotin-tftv (Tivdak) is an antibody-drug conjugate. This means it is a monoclonal antibody linked to a cancer-killing drug. The monoclonal antibody binds to a specific protein on the surface of a cancer cell, allowing the linked drug to enter and kill the cancer cell. Tivdak may also help the immune system kill cancer cells.

sections.heading: Immunotherapy for Cervical Cancer
content: Immunotherapy is the use of medicines to stimulate a person’s immune system to recognize and destroy cancer cells more effectively. Immunotherapy can be used to treat cervical cancer that has spread or come back (recurred).

Pembrolizumab ( Keytruda ) is an immunotherapy drug that is given in the vein every three weeks. It targets PD-1, a protein on immune system cells called T cells that normally helps keep these cells from attacking other cells in your body. By blocking PD-1, the drug boosts the immune response against cancer cells. This can shrink some tumors or slow their growth.
Pembrolizumab can be used in people with certain types of cervical cancer whose cancer starts growing again after chemotherapy or that has spread to other parts of their body.

By blocking PD-1, the drug boosts the immune response against cancer cells. This can shrink some tumors or slow their growth.
Pembrolizumab can be used in people with certain types of cervical cancer whose cancer starts growing again after chemotherapy or that has spread to other parts of their body.

sections.heading: Cervical Cancer Clinical Trials
content: If you've tried a few treatments and they didn't work or the cancer has spread, ask your doctor about a clinical trial . Trials test new cervical cancer treatments to see if they’re safe and if they work. They’re often ways for people to try new medicines or therapies that aren’t available to everyone. Your doctor can tell you if one of these trials might be a good fit for you.

Your doctor can tell you if one of these trials might be a good fit for you.

sections.heading: Questions to Ask the Doctor About Your Cervical Cancer Treatment
content: If you've been diagnosed with cervical cancer and you feel overwhelmed, consider making a list of questions to discuss with your doctor to help you better understand your cancer and what the next steps of your treatment will look like. Consider asking things like:
bullets: What does treatment look like for my stage of cancer?
Should I get a second opinion?
Will I get treatment at the hospital or at home?
What are the possible side effects of treatment?
What are my chances of recovery with this diagnosis?
Will treatment affect my ability to have kids?
Am I a good fit for a clinical trial?
Will any medicines I'm on interact with treatment?

sections.heading: How Can I Feel Better During Cervical Cancer Treatment?
content: You’re probably so focused on getting well, you hardly have time to think about how to ease the side effects from your treatments like hair loss or changes in your appetite. But there are things you can do that can help you feel better.

sections.heading: How Can I Feel Better During Cervical Cancer Treatment?
content: You’re probably so focused on getting well, you hardly have time to think about how to ease the side effects from your treatments like hair loss or changes in your appetite. But there are things you can do that can help you feel better.

content_blocks.text: You’re probably so focused on getting well, you hardly have time to think about how to ease the side effects from your treatments like hair loss or changes in your appetite. But there are things you can do that can help you feel better.

sections.heading: Manage your nutrition and weight.
content: Making good food choices during treatment can help you feel better, tolerate side effects, lower your chances of infection, and even heal faster. Try to eat a variety of foods so you get the nutrients you need, including:

Plant-based foods are a good source of vitamins and minerals. You should try to eat at least 2.5 cups of colorful fruits and vegetables daily, including citrus. Try new foods too, like beans, and keep high-fat foods from animals to a minimum.

Snacking throughout the day can help you get extra protein and calories to heal and keep your weight stable. Try to keep protein-rich snacks like yogurt, eggs, or cheese and crackers with you during the day. If you have side effects like sore throat or diarrhea, avoid snacking on acidic foods that can make them worse.
bullets: Proteins (fish, poultry, lean red meat, eggs, low-fat dairy products)

associated_bullets: Proteins (fish, poultry, lean red meat, eggs, low-fat dairy products)

content_blocks.text: Plant-based foods are a good source of vitamins and minerals. You should try to eat at least 2.5 cups of colorful fruits and vegetables daily, including citrus. Try new foods too, like beans, and keep high-fat foods from animals to a minimum.

Snacking throughout the day can help you get extra protein and calories to heal and keep your weight stable. Try to keep protein-rich snacks like yogurt, eggs, or cheese and crackers with you during the day. If you have side effects like sore throat or diarrhea, avoid snacking on acidic foods that can make them worse.

sections.heading: Exercise.
content: Your treatment program may make you feel extra tired, and exercise probably seems impossible. But even doing a small amount can have tons of benefits. It can help you stay strong, improve your appetite and energy, and help you feel less stressed or depressed.
Talk with your doctor about what exercise makes sense for you, and pay attention to how you feel when moving your body.
It’s OK to care about your appearance. Some medications can change how you look and that can affect how you feel about yourself. Managing these physical side effects may help you feel more confident.

The American Cancer Society sponsors a nationwide program called Look Good Feel Better that teaches beauty techniques to people with all kinds of cancer. Their volunteers give you tips on makeup, skin, and nails and help you with wigs and accessories if you have hair loss .

Talk to your doctor about your treatment plan and whether it will make you lose your hair. If you do, they should be able to write a prescription for a hair prosthesis so your insurance company will cover the cost of a wig. Some organizations also sell wigs and hair accessories specifically for people undergoing cancer treatment. Your doctor and your hairdresser might also have tips for keeping your hair while you go through treatment.

sections.heading: Talk about sexual side effects.
content: If you’re getting chemotherapy for cervical cancer, you may notice a loss of libido or other sexual side effects like vaginal dryness during and after treatment. This is because chemotherapy causes your ovaries to suddenly stop making estrogen . Your doctor can recommend estrogen replacement therapy or a topical estrogen cream.

Radiation therapy in your pelvic area can damage your ovaries and cause a change in your vaginal lining. Talk to your doctor about your treatment and whether they can recommend any specific strategies for preventing long-term side effects.
In some cases, other forms of intimacy may feel better than intercourse, so talk to your partner about new ways to connect.

Get emotional support. Consider joining a support group, whether in person or online, to connect with other people in the same situation. The National Cervical Cancer Coalition has an online community, and other organizations like CancerCare offer face-to-face, telephone, and online support.
You may also want to think about individual or family counseling to manage your physical and emotional changes. Ask your treatment team about recommendations and local resources.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Cervical cancer is usually very treatable, especially if you get regular screenings for it and catch it early. Treatment will depend on what stage your cancer is and whether or not you want to be able to have children after treatment. Your options may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, or a combination of any of these. Talk with your doctor about the best treatment plan for you.

content_blocks.text: Cervical cancer is usually very treatable, especially if you get regular screenings for it and catch it early. Treatment will depend on what stage your cancer is and whether or not you want to be able to have children after treatment. Your options may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, or a combination of any of these. Talk with your doctor about the best treatment plan for you.

sections.heading: Cervical Cancer Treatment FAQs
content: Is cervical cancer curable?
Everyone's cancer reacts differently to treatment, but when caught early through regular screenings, cervical cancer can often be successfully treated.
Can you get pregnant with cervical cancer?

It depends on how advanced your cancer is. In some cases, stage I cancers can be treated with surgeries that won't affect your ability to get pregnant later on. But if you have more progressed cervical cancer, you may need radiation or a hysterectomy (the surgical removal of your uterus), which will make you unable to get or stay pregnant.

But if you have more progressed cervical cancer, you may need radiation or a hysterectomy (the surgical removal of your uterus), which will make you unable to get or stay pregnant.

sections.heading: What is the best stage I cervical cancer treatment?
content: The best treatment for stage I cancer depends on how likely it is for your cancer to come back and whether or not you want to be able to get pregnant after treatment. A total hysterectomy might be the best treatment for you if you don't want to have kids, but if you still want that option and your cancer can be safely treated with another surgery, that may be the best option for you.
Can cervical cancer come back after treatment​?
Yes, about 1/3 of people who have had cervical cancer will see their cancer come back.
